libraries.format: {1} binds to the promoter region of {0}.
libraries.description: Transcription factor target genes inferred from PWMs for the human genome were downloaded from the UCSC Genome Browser (PMID: 17142222) FTP site which contains many resources for gene and sequence annotations. We converted this file into a gene set library and included it in Enrichr since it produces different results compared with the other method to identify transcription factor/target interactions from PWMs. PWMs from were used to scan the promoters of all human genes in the region ?2000 and +500 from the transcription factor start site (TSS). We retained only the 100% matches to the consensus sequences to call an interaction between a factor and target gene.
libraries.author: Ed Chen

libraries.format: {1} has a binding site at the promoter of {0}.
libraries.description: PWMs from TRANSFAC and JASPAR were used to scan the promoters of all human genes in the region ?2000 and +500 from the transcription factor start site (TSS). We retained only the 100% matches to the consensus sequences to call an interaction between a factor and target gene. This gene-set library was created for a tool we previously published called Expression2Kinases (PMID: 22080467).
libraries.author: Ed Chen

libraries.format: {0} is associated with the histone modification, {1}.
{1} physically interacts with {0}.
libraries.author: Avi Ma'ayan

libraries.format: {1} binds to the promoter region of {0}.
libraries.description: The ChIP-x Enrichment Analysis (ChEA) database (PMID: 20709693) is our own resource for storing putative targets for transcription factors extracted from publications that report experiments of profiling transcription factors binding to DNA in mammalian cells. The database is already formatted into a gene-set library where the functional terms are the transcription factors profiled in each study together with the PubMed identifier (PMID) of the paper used to extract the gene. The ChEA gene-set library used in Enrichr is an updated version from the originally published database containing more than twice the entries compared to the originally published version.
libraries.author: Alex Lachmann

libraries.format: {0} is differentially expressed when {1} is perturbed.
libraries.description: The Gene Expression Omnibus contains many published gene expression profiles.  We downloaded gene expression data for kinase perturbations compared to control and computed signatures of differentially expressed genes using the characteristic direction method.  Each line of the GMT file corresponds to a particular kinase perturbation experiment.  Each line is either a set of up-regulated genes or down-regulated genes.  This file is missing the description for each line that actually identifies the condition and whether the set of genes was up-regulated or down-regulated.
libraries.author: Andrew Rouillard

libraries.format: {1} is differentially expressed when the cell is perturbed with {0}.
libraries.description: Differentially expressed genes are obtained  by processing the gene expression data deposited in GEO using characteristic direction.
libraries.author: Axel Feldmann

libraries.format: {1} binds to the promoter region of {0}.
libraries.description: For the ENCODE transcription factor gene-set library, we processed the newly published data from the Encyclopedia of DNA Elements (ENCODE) project (PMID: 22075998;PMID: 22955616). Using the aligned files for all 646 experiments that profiled transcription factors in mammalian cells, we identified the peaks using the MACS software (PMID: 18798982) and then identified the genes targeted by the factors using our own custom processing. We sorted the peaks for each experiment by distance to the transcription factor start site (TSS) and retained the top 2000 target genes for each experiment.
libraries.author: Yan Kou

libraries.format: {0} is a member of the {1}.
libraries.description: The pathway associated gene-set library was created from the Biocarta database by converting members of each pathway from the pathway database to a list of human genes.
libraries.author: Broad

libraries.format: {0} is a member of the {1}.
libraries.description: The pathway associated gene-set library was created from the Reactome database (PMID: 15608231) by converting members of each pathway from the pathway database to a list of human genes.
libraries.author: Alex Lachmann

libraries.format: {0} is a member of the {1} pathway.
libraries.description: The pathway associated gene-set library was created from the WikiPathways database (PMID: 18651794) by converting members of each pathway from the pathway database to a list of human genes.
libraries.author: Alex Lachmann

libraries.format: {0} is up-regulated in {1} tissue.
{0} is a member of the {1} pathway.
libraries.description: The pathway associated gene-set library was created from the KEGG database (PMID: 9715755) by converting members of each pathway from the pathway database to a list of human genes.
libraries.author: Alex Lachmann

libraries.format: {1} is affected when {0} is knocked down.
{0} is the predicted target of {1}.
{0} directly interacts with the hub protein {1}.
libraries.description: The protein-protein interaction hubs gene-set library is made from an updated version of a human protein-protein interaction network that we are continually updating and originally published as part of the program, Expression2Kinases (PMID: 22080467). From this network, we extracted the proteins with 120 or more interactions. These proteins are the terms in the library whereas their direct protein interactors are the genes in each gene set.
libraries.author: Amin Mazloom

libraries.format: {0} has the molecular function of {1}.
{0} is found in the table of {1}.
libraries.description: The GeneSigDB gene-set library was borrowed from the GeneSigDB database (PMID:22110038). The database contains gene lists extracted manually from the supporting tables of thousands of publications; most are from cancer related studies.
libraries.author: Broad

libraries.format: {0} is found in chromosome segment {1}.
libraries.description: The chromosomal location library is made of human genes belonging to chromosomal segments of the human genome. It is derived from MSigDB (PMID: 21546393).
libraries.author: Broad

libraries.format: {0} is up-regulated in {1} cells.
libraries.description: The library is created from genes highly expressed in human tissues extracted from the Mouse and Human Gene Atlases (PMID: 15075390). The Human Gene Atlas dataset was derived from averaged GCRMA-normalized mRNA expression data from the BioGPS site. The downloaded data was in a table with the rows being the genes and the columns being the expression values in the different cells. For each gene, the average and standard deviation of the expression values across all samples were computed. For each gene/term data point, a z-score was calculated based on the row's average and standard deviation. Duplicate gene probes were merged by selecting the highest absolute z-score. Only genes with an absolute z-score of greater than 3 were selected to be part of a gene set for a particular cell which represents the term.
libraries.author: Ed Chen

libraries.format: {0} is up-regulated in {1} cells.
libraries.description: The library is created from genes highly expressed in mouse tissues extracted from the Mouse and Human Gene Atlases (PMID: 15075390). The Mouse Gene Atlas dataset was derived from averaged GCRMA-normalized mRNA expression data from the BioGPS site. The downloaded data was in a table with the rows being the genes and the columns being the expression values in the different cells. For each gene, the average and standard deviation of the expression values across all samples were computed. For each gene/term data point, a z-score was calculated based on the row's average and standard deviation. Duplicate gene probes were merged by selecting the highest absolute z-score. Only genes with an absolute z-score of greater than 3 were selected to be part of a gene set for a particular cell which represents the term.
libraries.author: Ed Chen

libraries.format: {0} is found in {1}.
{0} is involved in the biological process {1}.
{0} is found in {1}.
{0} is associated with the histone modification, {1}.
libraries.description: The Histone modification gene-set library was created by processing experiments from the NIH Roadmap Epigenomics (PMID: 22690667). Such experiments were conducted using various types of human cell lines types with antibodies targeting over 30 different histone modification marks. ChIP-seq datasets from the Roadmap Epigenomics project deposited to the GEO database were analyzed and converted to gene sets with the use of the software, SICER (PMID: 19505939). Previous studies (PMID: 19844228) have indicated that the use of control sample substantially reduces DNA shearing biases and sequencing artifacts; therefore, for each experiment, an input control sample was matched according to the description in GEO. ChIP-seq experiments without matched control input were not included. The resulting gene-set library contains 27 types of histone modifications for 64 human cell lines from various tissue origins.
libraries.author: Yan Kou

libraries.format: {1} phosphorylates {0}.
libraries.description: The Kinase Enrichment Analysis (KEA) gene-set library (PMID: 19176546) contains human or mouse kinases and their known substrates collected from literature reports as provided by six kinase-substrate databases: HPRD (PMID: 18988627), PhosphoSite (PMID: 15174125), PhosphoPoint (PMID: 18689816), Phospho. Elm (PMID: 15212693), NetworKIN (PMID: 17981841), and MINT (PMID: 11911893).
libraries.author: Alex Lachmann

libraries.format: {0} was found in a complex with the {1} complexome.
{0} is part of the {1}.
libraries.description: This protein complexes gene-set library was created from the mammalian complexes database, CORUM (PMID: 19884131).
libraries.author: Amin Mazloom

libraries.format: {0} is phosphorylated in the {1} condition.
libraries.description: The SILAC phosphoproteomics gene set library was created by processing tables from the supporting materials of SILAC phosphoproteomics studies (PMID: 19241009). From each supporting table, we extracted lists of up and down proteins without applying any cutoffs. Protein IDs were converted to mammalian gene IDs when necessary using online gene symbol conversion tools. A total of 84 gene lists were extracted from such studies.
libraries.author: Marylens Hernandez

libraries.format: {0} is differentially expressed when {1} is perturbed.
libraries.description: Signatures (22268 full genes) of ~100 up-regulated or down-regulated genes following kinase knockdown.  These signatures were downloaded using the lincscloud API.  Each line of the GMT file corresponds to a particular shRNA, cell line, and time point.  Each line is either a set of up-regulated genes or down-regulated genes.  This is only a partial file.  The full library of signatures for kinase knockdowns is much larger.  This file is missing the description for each line that actually identifies the condition and whether the set of genes was up-regulated or down-regulated.
libraries.author: Andrew Rouillard

libraries.format: Knockdown of {0} results in {1} phenotype.
libraries.description: The MGI Mammalian Phenotype library was created from the knockout mouse phenotypes ontology developed by the Jackson Lab from their MGI-MP browser (PMID: 18981050). We "cut" the tree at either the third or fourth level and created a gene set from the terms and their associated genes downstream the cut.
libraries.author: Alex Lachmann

libraries.format: Knockdown of {0} results in {1} phenotype.
libraries.description: The MGI Mammalian Phenotype library was created from the knockout mouse phenotypes ontology developed by the Jackson Lab from their MGI-MP browser (PMID: 18981050). We "cut" the tree at either the third or fourth level and created a gene set from the terms and their associated genes downstream the cut.
libraries.author: Alex Lachmann

libraries.format: In cells treated by the drug {1}, {0} is up-regulated.
libraries.description: The Connectivity Map (CMAP) database (PMID: 17008526) contains over 6,000 Affymetrix microarray gene expression experiments where human cancer cell lines were treated with over 1,300 drugs, many of them FDA approved, and changes in expression where measured after six hours. The drugs were always used as a single treatment but varied in concentrations. The CMAP database provides the results in a table where genes are listed in rank order based on their level of differential expression compared to the untreated state. From this table, we extracted the top 100 and bottom 100 differentially expressed genes to create two gene-set libraries, one for the up genes and one for the down genes for each condition. Each set is associated with a drug name and the four digit experiment number from CMAP. This four digit number can be used to locate the concentration, cell-type, and batch.
libraries.author: Ed Chen

libraries.format: In cells treated by the drug {1}, {0} is down-regulated.
libraries.description: The Connectivity Map (CMAP) database (PMID: 17008526) contains over 6,000 Affymetrix microarray gene expression experiments where human cancer cell lines were treated with over 1,300 drugs, many of them FDA approved, and changes in expression where measured after six hours. The drugs were always used as a single treatment but varied in concentrations. The CMAP database provides the results in a table where genes are listed in rank order based on their level of differential expression compared to the untreated state. From this table, we extracted the top 100 and bottom 100 differentially expressed genes to create two gene-set libraries, one for the up genes and one for the down genes for each condition. Each set is associated with a drug name and the four digit experiment number from CMAP. This four digit number can be used to locate the concentration, cell-type, and batch.
libraries.author: Ed Chen

libraries.format: {0} is associated with the genetic disease {1}.
libraries.description: The OMIM gene-set library was created directly from the NCBI's OMIM Morbid Map (PMID: 15608251). We removed diseases with only a few genes and merged diseases with similar names because these are likely made of few subtypes of the same disease.
libraries.author: Avi Ma'ayan

libraries.format: {0} is associated with a subnetwork around the genetic disease {1}.
libraries.description: The OMIM gene-set library was created directly from the NCBI's OMIM Morbid Map (PMID: 15608251). We removed diseases with only a few genes and merged diseases with similar names because these are likely made of few subtypes of the same disease. In addition, since most diseases have only few genes, we used our tool, Genes2Networks (PMID: 17916244), to create the OMIM expanded gene-set library. We entered the disease genes as the seed list and expanded the list by identifying proteins that directly interact with at least two of the disease gene products; in other words, we searched for paths that connect two disease gene products with one intermediate protein, resulting in a subnetwork that connects the disease genes with additional proteins/genes. Each sub-network for each disease was converted to a gene set.
libraries.author: Avi Ma'ayan

libraries.format: {0} interacts with a viral protein from {1}.
libraries.description: The VirusMINT gene-set library was created from the VirusMINT database (PMID: 18974184), which is made of literature extracted protein-protein interactions between viral proteins and human proteins. Each term in the library represents a virus wherein the genes/proteins in each set are the host proteins that are known to directly interact with all the viral proteins for each virus.
libraries.author: Avi Ma'ayan

libraries.format: {0} is associated with the {1} MSigDB module.
libraries.description: The MSigDB computational and MSigDB oncogenic signature gene-set libraries were borrowed from the MSigDB database from categories C4 and C6 (PMID: 21546393). These gene-set libraries contain modules of genes differentially expressed in various cancers.
libraries.author: Broad

libraries.format: {0} is found in the {1} oncogenic signature.
libraries.description: The MSigDB computational and MSigDB oncogenic signature gene-set libraries were borrowed from the MSigDB database from categories C4 and C6 (PMID: 21546393). These gene-set libraries contain modules of genes differentially expressed in various cancers.
libraries.author: Broad

libraries.format: {0} is down-regulated in {1} tissue.
{0} is up-regulated in tissue infected with {1}.
{0} is down-regulated in tissue infected with {1}.
{0} is up-regulated in {1} cells.
libraries.description: The library is made from genes highly expressed in cancer cell lines from the Cancer Cell Line Encyclopedia (CCLE) (PMID: 22460905). The Cancer Cell Line Encyclopedia (CCLE) dataset was derived from the gene-centric RMAnormalized mRNA expression data from the CCLE site.The downloaded data was in a table with the rows being the genes and the columns being the expression values in the different cells. For each gene, the average and standard deviation of the expression values across all samples were computed. For each gene/term data point, a z-score was calculated based on the row's average and standard deviation. Duplicate gene probes were merged by selecting the highest absolute z-score. Only genes with an absolute z-score of greater than 3 were selected to be part of a gene set for a particular cell which represents the term.
libraries.author: Ed Chen

libraries.format: {0} is up-regulated in {1} cells.
libraries.description: The library is created from genes highly expressed in cancer cell lines from the NCI-60 (PMID: 17088435).
libraries.author: Ed Chen

libraries.format: {0} is up-regulated in {1} cells.
{0} is up-regulated in {1} cells.
{1} is a co-factor of {0}.
libraries.description: The library was created from HMDB, a database (PMID: 17202168) enlisting metabolites and the genes associated with them
libraries.author: Amin Mazloom

libraries.format: {0} has a {1} protein domain.
libraries.description: the structural domains library was created from the PFAM (PMID: 14681378) and InterPro (PMID: 11125043) databases where the terms are structural domains and the genes/proteins are the genes containing the domains.
libraries.author: Amin Mazloom

libraries.format: {0} is involved in the biological process {1}.
libraries.description: The Gene Ontology Biological Process library was created from the gene ontology tree of biological processes (PMID: 10802651). We "cut" the tree at either the third or fourth level and created a gene set from the terms and their associated genes downstream the cut.
libraries.author: Alex Lachmann

libraries.format: {0} is found in {1}.
libraries.description: The Gene Ontology Celluar Component library was created from the gene ontology tree of cellular components (PMID: 10802651). We "cut" the tree at either the third or fourth level and created a gene set from the terms and their associated genes downstream the cut.
libraries.author: Alex Lachmann

libraries.format: {0} has the molecular function of {1}.
libraries.description: The Gene Ontology Molecular Function library was created from the gene ontology tree of molecular functions (PMID: 10802651). We "cut" the tree at either the third or fourth level and created a gene set from the terms and their associated genes downstream the cut.
libraries.author: Alex Lachmann

libraries.format: {0} is up-regulated in {1} cells.
{1} binds to the promoter region of {0}.
{0} is associated with the histone modification, {1}.
{1} dephosphorylates the protein {0}.
{0} is down-regulated in {1} cells.
{0} is associated with the histone modification, {1}.
libraries.description: For the ENCODE HM gene-set library, we processed the newly published data from the Encyclopedia of DNA Elements (ENCODE) project (PMID: 22075998;PMID: 22955616). We mapped the narrowPeak files to the genome. We sorted the peaks for each experiment by distance to the transcription factor start site (TSS) and retained the top 2000 target genes for each experiment.
libraries.author: Yan Kou

Knockdown of {0} decreases the fitness of the {1} cell line.
Knockdown of {0} results in {1} phenotype.

{0} is related to {1}.

libraries.description: The Connectivity Map (CMAP) database (PMID: 17008526) contains over 6,000 Affymetrix microarray gene expression experiments where human cancer cell lines were treated with over 1,300 drugs, many of them FDA approved, and changes in expression where measured after six hours. The drugs were always used as a single treatment but varied in concentrations. The CMAP database provides the results in a table where genes are listed in rank order based on their level of differential expression compared to the untreated state. From this table, we extracted the top 500 and bottom 500 differentially expressed genes to create two gene-set libraries, one for the up genes and one for the down genes for each condition. Each set is associated with a drug name and the four digit experiment number from CMAP. This four digit number can be used to locate the concentration, cell-type, and batch.
libraries.author: Ed Chen

libraries.description: The Connectivity Map (CMAP) database (PMID: 17008526) contains over 6,000 Affymetrix microarray gene expression experiments where human cancer cell lines were treated with over 1,300 drugs, many of them FDA approved, and changes in expression where measured after six hours. The drugs were always used as a single treatment but varied in concentrations. The CMAP database provides the results in a table where genes are listed in rank order based on their level of differential expression compared to the untreated state. From this table, we extracted the top 500 and bottom 500 differentially expressed genes to create two gene-set libraries, one for the up genes and one for the down genes for each condition. Each set is associated with a drug name and the four digit experiment number from CMAP. This four digit number can be used to locate the concentration, cell-type, and batch.
libraries.author: Ed Chen

libraries.description: Signatures of ~100 up-regulated or down-regulated genes following kinase knockdown.  These signatures were downloaded using the lincscloud API.  Each line of the GMT file corresponds to a particular shRNA, cell line, and time point.  Each line is either a set of up-regulated genes or down-regulated genes.  For each of 274 kinases, two conditions (shRNA, cell line, time point) were selected based on strength of agreement of replicate gene signatures.  This file is missing the description for each line that actually identifies the condition and whether the set of genes was up-regulated or down-regulated.
libraries.author: Andrew

libraries.description: The Level 3 microarray gene expression data was downloaded for each patient from TCGA. The significantly up-regulated genes for each patient is extracted by taking z score over 1.96 or 2.33.
libraries.author: Yan

libraries.description: The Level 3 microarray gene expression data was downloaded for each patient from TCGA. The significantly up-regulated genes for each patient is extracted by taking z score over 1.96 or 2.33.
libraries.author: Yan Kou

libraries.description: The Histone modification gene-set library was created by processing experiments from the NIH Roadmap Epigenomics (PMID: 22690667). Such experiments were conducted using various types of human cell lines types with antibodies targeting over 30 different histone modification marks. ChIP-seq datasets from the Roadmap Epigenomics project deposited to the GEO database were analyzed and converted to gene sets with the use of the software, SICER (PMID: 19505939). Previous studies (PMID: 19844228) have indicated that the use of control sample substantially reduces DNA shearing biases and sequencing artifacts; therefore, for each experiment, an input control sample was matched according to the description in GEO. ChIP-seq experiments without matched control input were not included. The resulting gene-set library contains 27 types of histone modifications for 64 human cell lines from various tissue origins.
libraries.author: Yan Kou

libraries.description: The L1000 sig_summly tool computes consensus signatures of DE genes for perturbations across all conditions, and then ranks the similarity of consensus signatures for all pairs of perturbations (see link for more detail).  Each line of this set library lists the top 20 knockdowns that are most similar to the labeled knockdown.
libraries.author: Andrew

libraries.description: The L1000 sig_summly tool computes consensus signatures of DE genes for perturbations across all conditions, and then ranks the similarity of consensus signatures for all pairs of perturbations (see link for more detail).  Each line of this set library lists the top 20 overexpressions that are most similar to the labeled knockdown.
libraries.author: Andrew

libraries.description: The L1000 sig_summly tool computes consensus signatures of DE genes for perturbations across all conditions, and then ranks the similarity of consensus signatures for all pairs of perturbations (see link for more detail).  Each line of this set library lists the top 20 knockdowns that are most similar to the labeled compound treatment.
libraries.author: Andrew

Each line of this set library lists the top 20 overexpressions that are most similar to the labeled compound treatment.

Each line of this set library lists the top 20 overexpressions that are most similar to the labeled overexpression.
libraries.author: Andrew Rouillard

libraries.description: The L1000 sig_summly tool computes consensus signatures of DE genes for perturbations across all conditions, and then ranks the similarity of consensus signatures for all pairs of perturbations (see link for more detail).  Each line of this set library lists the top 30 knockdowns that are most similar to the labeled kinase knockdown.
libraries.author: Andrew Rouillard

libraries.description: The Gene Expression Omnibus contains many published gene expression profiles.  We downloaded gene expression data for kinase perturbations compared to control and computed signatures of differentially expressed genes using the ttest method.  Each line of the GMT file corresponds to a particular kinase perturbation experiment.  Each line is either a set of up-regulated genes or down-regulated genes.  This file is missing the description for each line that actually identifies the condition and whether the set of genes was up-regulated or down-regulated.
